subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] among and above have
msgSnippet: While I agree totally about up I think it s interesting that one of the examples you culled from the resource s dictionary raises its own issues: upon ,
messageBody:
While I agree totally about "up" I think it's
interesting that one of the examples you culled from
the resource''s dictionary raises its own issues:
"upon", which uses number 32 instead of 34 for the
second vowel; this, even though 1) Read himself calls
#34 "on" and 2) the American Heritage Dictionary
gives its equivalent of #34 as the preferred
pronunciation.

I don't mean to quibble, but just to point out that
certain vowel issues have been with us for years, and
I guess will always be with us, and a
computer-generated phonemic dictionary is only as good
as its phonemes.

Has anybody come up with a sure-fire distinction
between "on" and "calm"? Something you could explain
to the proverbial Martian?

Signed (a white bread American)


--- Chuck Peck <chuck091956@...> wrote:

> Hello All,
>
> This is how I think the American English Dictionary
> would spell them. From
> the attached graphics, I don't think there is any
> difference between the
> "up" sounds in them.
>
> This is from the dictionary that is located in the
> "Files
> <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/>
> > Resources" section
> of the web site. That dictionary was build from a
> phonic database.
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Chuck
>

interesting that one of the examples you culled from

"upon", which uses number 32 instead of 34 for the
second vowel; this, even though 1) Read himself  calls

gives  its equivalent of #34 as the preferred

I don't mean to quibble, but just to  point out  that
certain vowel issues have been with us for years, and
I guess will always be with us, and a 
computer-generated phonemic dictionary is only as good
as its phonemes.

Has anybody come up with a sure-fire distinction
between  "on" and "calm"? Something you could explain
to the proverbial Martian?

Signed (a white bread American)
